title: Default Constructor
A
default constructor
i
is a type of constructor that requires no parameters when called. It is named after the type it constructs and is a member function of it (as all constructors are).

inline_content.Text: A
default constructor
is a type of constructor that requires no parameters when called. It is named after the type it constructs and is a member function of it (as all constructors are).

title: Another way to satisfy the “no parameters” requirement is for the developer to provide default values for all parameters:

inline_content.Text: Another way to satisfy the “no parameters” requirement is for the developer to provide default values for all parameters:

title: D d; // calls constructor of D with the provided default values for the parameters

content_resolved.code: D d; // calls constructor of D with the provided default values for the parameters

title: Under some circumstances (i.e., the developer provides no constructors and there are no other disqualifying conditions), the compiler implicitly provides an empty default constructor:

inline_content.Text: Under some circumstances (i.e., the developer provides no constructors and there are no other disqualifying conditions), the compiler implicitly provides an empty default constructor:

title: Having some other type of constructor is one of the disqualifying conditions mentioned earlier:

inline_content.Text: Having some other type of constructor is one of the disqualifying conditions mentioned earlier:

title: To prevent implicit default constructor creation, a common technique is to declare it as
private
c
(with no definition). The intention is to cause a compile error when someone tries to use the constructor (this either results in an
Access to private
i
error or a linker error, depending on the compiler).

inline_content.Text: To prevent implicit default constructor creation, a common technique is to declare it as
private
(with no definition). The intention is to cause a compile error when someone tries to use the constructor (this either results in an
Access to private
error or a linker error, depending on the compiler).

title: To be sure a default constructor (functionally similar to the implicit one) is defined, a developer could write an empty one explicitly.

inline_content.Text: To be sure a default constructor (functionally similar to the implicit one) is defined, a developer could write an empty one explicitly.

title: In C++11, a developer can also use the
delete
c
keyword to prevent the compiler from providing a default constructor.

inline_content.Text: In C++11, a developer can also use the
delete
keyword to prevent the compiler from providing a default constructor.

title: Furthermore, a developer may also be explicit about wanting the compiler to provide a default constructor.

inline_content.Text: Furthermore, a developer may also be explicit about wanting the compiler to provide a default constructor.

title: You can determine whether a type has a default constructor (or is a primitive type) using
std::is_default_constructible
c
from
<type_traits>
c

inline_content.Text: You can determine whether a type has a default constructor (or is a primitive type) using
std::is_default_constructible
from
<type_traits>

title: In C++11, it is still possible to use the non-functor version of
std::is_default_constructible
c

inline_content.Text: In C++11, it is still possible to use the non-functor version of
std::is_default_constructible

title: cout << boolalpha << is_default_constructible<C1>::value << endl; // prints true

content_resolved.code: cout << boolalpha << is_default_constructible<C1>::value << endl; // prints true
